prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Limitations on Panel's power—Multidistrict cases only

para.paratext: The Panel does not have any authority to coordinate or consolidate cases pending within a single judicial district.[1] The Panel has noted that many courts have provided for assignment of such cases to a single judge by local rule and has approved such handling of cases by the district courts.[2] The Panel does not interfere in the handling of these purely local issues of judicial management, and a strict reading of the statute makes it clear that the Panel is authorized to act only when actions “are pending in different districts.”[3] The Panel has also declined to transfer cases where it appears that the local assignment mechanisms may provide sufficient means for managing the litigation.[4]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See, e.g., In re Grain Shipments, 305 F. Supp. 3 (J.P.M.L. 1969).

See, e.g., In re USS Trenton Disaster Litigation, 383 F. Supp. 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1974); In re Harmony Loan Co., Inc. Securities Litigation, 372 F. Supp. 1406, 1407 (J.P.M.L. 1974). Many districts have established procedures by local rule providing for transfer of related cases to a single judge for handling of pretrial proceedings. See, e.g., S.D. Ala. R. 4; C.D. Cal. R. 4; E.D. Cal. R. 123; N.D. Cal. R. 205 & 206; D. Colo. R. 203; D. Del. R. 2.2(B); D.D.C. R. 3 to 4; S.D. Fla. R. 6; M.D. Fla. R. 1.04; S.D. Ga. R. 2.6; D. Haw. R. 206; N.D. 111. R. 2.31; D. Mass. R. 8(e); W.D. Mich. R.7(e)(4); S.D. Miss. R. 9; S.D. & E.D.N.Y. R. 15; E.D.N.Y. R. for Division of Bus. Among Dist. Judges 3; D. P.R. R. 302.5; (I). R.I. R. 31; S.D. Tex. R. 5. For thoughtful discussion of how this power was used in the District of Louisiana for the cases arising after Hurricane Katrina, see Edward F. Sherman, The MDL Model for Resolving Complex Litigation if a Class Action is Not Possible, 82 Tul. L. Rev. 2205, 2221–22 (2008).

The Panel is likely to transfer cases to a judge already supervising coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in cases already pending in the transferee district. This factor is discussed in §§ 6:8, 6:14 & 7:6.
28 U.S.C.A. § 1407(a). The statute is reproduced in § 3:19.
See, e.g., In re Harmony Loan Co., Inc. Securities Litigation, 372 F. Supp. 1406, 1407 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
